awd_titl_txt: CRISP 2.0 Type 2: Collaborative Research: Water and Health Infrastructure Resilience and Learning (WHIRL)
awd_abstract_narration:
Drinking water and public health systems are some of the most critical infrastructures that support human well-being. This Critical Resilient Interdependent Infrastructure Systems and Processes (CRISP) project will provide new insights about how these systems interact with each other and adapt to challenges. The project will also investigate how the public learns about and engages with public health and water systems. The focus will be to assess how a range of disruptions, from routine challenges to large-scale disasters, alter public interactions with these systems. Study data will include interviews with subject matter experts from water utilities and public health agencies. It will also include a national survey to understand how well these US infrastructures can adapt to future challenges. Information gained from project partners and the national survey will develop approaches that can be used to identify factors and develop models to enhance resilience of both systems. This project will advance knowledge that can be used to promote access to cleaner, safer drinking water for all communities, including the socially and economically disadvantaged ones. It will serve the national interest by identifying approaches to improve management for, and communication methods between, water and public health systems, thereby improving the health, prosperity and welfare of communities. Collaborations with the Water Research Foundation (WRF), National Association of County and City Health Officials (NACCHO), American Indian Mothers, Inc. and others, will assist in translating research results to new practices and policies that reduce the burden of disease in vulnerable populations. The project will also provide training to students, including underrepresented minorities, in STEM.

The research will make theoretical contributions in two primary areas. First, it will build upon organizational learning theory as it is manifest from risks, hazard and disruptions in water events and ground this within systems theory and organizational sense-making. Outcomes include new norms, procedures, structures, capacity and technology designed to promote higher reliability and resilience. This will include describing the ways risk, hazards and failures impact public policy agendas and policy learning outcomes. Second, this research will contribute to theoretical work on resilience in critical infrastructure by connecting the social, managerial, and technical frameworks as manifest around water events. Emerging risks with unknown impact include shrinking cities, decaying infrastructure and persistent under-funding. Transformative aspects of the project include creating theoretical models that describe how the relationship of communities to these coupled interdependent systems shapes organizational learning from disruptions, and in turn enacting changes that enhance resilience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Water and Health Infrastructure Resilience and Learning (WHIRL) is a collaborative project that explored ways in which (i) water utilities, (ii) public health departments, and (iii) users of both interact during times of disruption.  We focus on disruptions (e.g., loss of water services that causes a public health risk) and how all three learn, change behavior, and develop resilience because of past experiences with disruptions.  As a collaborative project, the University of Michigan's role was focused on implementing water monitoring within the community, and evaluating (a) how water quality changes at the point of use over time and (b) how users in a community with a history of distrust in water quality and providers change perceptions as a result of having access to more information about their local water quality.  As part of this project, we also developed a process for easy monitoring of water quality by users based on cell-phone and cloud-based image processing of a test strip dipped in water.  We eventually employed the test strip system in the community to understand if it was sufficiently user-friendly.  There are three outcomes from this work. First, we successfully completed a test-of-concept for the test strip -based measurement of water quality. It proved to be a reliable way to determine if disinfectant residual in drinking water is adequate based on state standards, and was sufficiently sensitive to distinguish minimum threshold values that are considered inadequate for consumption.  Second, we used a community-based participatory approach to develop relationships with community leaders, hire community liaisons as research partners, and conduct in-home water quality real-time monitoring over four weeks in 24 homes in the Detroit-based neighborhood community.  Participants were surveyed at the beginning, end, and several weeks after monitoring ended to evaluate changes in perception about their water. Participants received incentives for their involvement in the study and received all water quality information plus lead testing results in the form of a written report.  The outcomes of the field-based monitoring work showed that while water quality was highly stable across all homes throughout the 9-month field campaign, the concentration of disinfectant residual in the neighborhood was routinely lower than the goal the utility set for itself.  Furthermore, while lead was below the action level in all but one home, it was present in several homes.  Third, using the community-liaison approach resulted in our team being viewed as trusted agents. Many participants developed improved perceptions of their water quality as a result of the study and even changed behaviors (e.g., purchased less bottled water).  However, distrust of the water provider did not improve, yet our results show that more transparency around sharing water quality data can improve trust.  Overall, the results from this study provide substantial insight into methods and tools that can be effectively used as part of an effort to build community knowledge and trust around drinking water, which is a form of resilience in the face of future disturbances in the system.
